title: Remove Duplicates from Sorted List
question_content:
Given the head of a sorted linked list, delete all duplicates such that each element appears only once. Return the linked list sorted as well.
 
Example 1:

Input: head = [1,1,2]
Output: [1,2]

Example 2:

Input: head = [1,1,2,3,3]
Output: [1,2,3]

 
Constraints:

	The number of nodes in the list is in the range [0, 300].
	-100 <= Node.val <= 100
	The list is guaranteed to be sorted in ascending order.

solutions.content:
# Approach
- We first deal with edge case of head being `None` rather than a `ListNode`
- Next we create a new variable `curr` to point at our current node, starting with the `head` node
- If `curr.next` is another node, we compare `curr.val` and `curr.next.val`
    - If the values are the same, we must remove one from the linked list
        - We keep the first node and remove the second by updating the first's .next (`curr.next`) to the next node's `.next` (`curr.next.next`)
    - If the values differ, we move point `curr` to the next node
- We repeat the previous process until the current node does not point to another node, at which point we return `head`, the de-duplicated linked list

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        if not head:
            return None

        curr = head

        while curr.next:
            if curr.val == curr.next.val:
                curr.next = curr.next.next
            else:
                curr = curr.next

        return head

```

solutions.content:
```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.next = None

class Solution(object):
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head):
        """
        :type head: ListNode
        :rtype: ListNode
        """
        first, second = head, head.next if head else None
        while second:
            if first.val == second.val:
                second = second.next
                first.next = second
            else:
                first = second
                second = second.next
                
        return head
```

solutions.content:
Recursively remove duplicates from the rest of the list, then possibly drop the head (if it's a duplicate of the value after it).

Ruby:

    def delete_duplicates(h)
        h && (h.next = delete_duplicates(h.next)) && h.next.val == h.val ? h.next : h
    end

---

Bad C++ versions:

    return h && (h->next = deleteDuplicates(h->next)) && h->next->val == h->val ? h->next : h;

As @shawnyi pointed out, that leaks memory. So `delete`:

    if (h && (h->next = deleteDuplicates(h->next)) && h->next->val == h->val) delete h, h = h->next; return h;

As @drbombe pointed out, I shouldn't access `h->next` after deleting `h`. Not sure what I was thinking. I certainly knew that. I guess I just focused on the algorithm and didn't care as long as it gets accepted (which it does).

For a proper version, see @drbombe's solution below.

solutions.content:
**O(N) Time & O(1) Space Solution**
```
def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
	front = head #points to the front of the linked list
	while head and head.next: #while we aren't at the end of the list
		if head.val == head.next.val: #if the next node has the same value
			head.next = head.next.next #skip it
		else: #not a duplicate
			head = head.next #otherwise move forward
	return front #return the front of the linked list
```
In this solution, we use ```front``` to keep track of the front of the linkedlist. Then, we go through the list up until the end and check to see if the value of the current node is equal to the value of the next node. If it is, then we skip the duplicate node by setting ```head.next = head.next.next```. If we just removed a duplicate, we don't know if the next node is also a duplicate, so we should not move forward with ```head = head.next``` like we do when we do not find a duplicate.
This solution only needs to look at every node once, giving ```O(N)``` time complexity. Since it requires a constant amount of additional space, the memory complexity is ```O(1)```.

P.S. ```while head and head.next``` is the same as ```while head is not None and head.next is not None``` –– it just checks that neither of them are ```None```.

**Thanks for Reading!**
If this post has been helpful, please consider upvoting! Also, if I made any mistakes or there are other optimizations, methods I didn't consider, etc. please let me know!

**Memory Usage: 13.8 MB, less than 70.70% of Python3 online submissions for Remove Duplicates from Sorted List.**

The theme to solve this question is just like how we solve regular linked list problems. 

We go with initializing two variables start and node with head then we move node to start.next

Like in this example:-
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/3c2f7589-5374-43a1-9c56-c0e8f203a2f6_1657981559.5628524.png)
 now `start` is 1 and `node` is 1(2nd one)
 we loop through the list and check if `start==node` and if that is true like in this case, what we need to do is set `start.next=node.next` now since the First `1` in the above diagram now points to `2` and the next thing we need to take care of is that we need to change this as I have illustated in the following pictures:-
 
 ![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/ecaeab50-b851-4dfa-94c7-7614a0402709_1658518230.7136285.jpeg)
 ![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/94b27264-6072-4f8a-b1a3-705ac89a2012_1658518253.6033578.jpeg)
 ![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/54f6551d-388c-43f3-9d1a-561c08359025_1658518264.8918567.jpeg)

 
From here it's cake walk, you need to continue the loop and that's it. The Probelm is Solved!!

**Code**
```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        if not head or not head.next:
            return head 
        start=node=head
        node=head.next
        while start and node:
            if start.val==node.val:
                start.next=node.next
                node.next=None
                node=start.next
            else:
                start=start.next
                node=node.next
        return head
```

solutions.content:
If you like the solution, your upvote is appreciated! 🤝

Explanation:

In the first while loop, we continue as long as the current node and the next node exist.

In the second while loop, we continue to replace the next value, if it is the same as the current value. In a sense, we skip the next value if it is the same.

When we reach the end of the linked list, and current node or next node is None, we can return the linked list from the beginning (head).

And that is it!

If you did not yet, upvote to make my day 🌞

```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution(object):
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head):
        """
        :type head: ListNode
        :rtype: ListNode
        """
        
        current = head
        
    
        while current != None and current.next != None:
              while current.val == current.next.val:
                    current.next = current.next.next
                    if current.next == None:
                        break
              current = current.next
        return head
```

solutions.title: c-java-explained-w-visual
solutions.content:
Runtime Complexity: **`O(n)`**
Space Complexity: **`O(1)`** (in-place)

**There are two main actions to know:**

#### (1) Traversal with a pointer: ```ptr = ptr.next;```
#### (2) Deletion of a target node: ```prev.next = target.next;``` or ```prev.next = prev.next.next;```

We will iterate through the list with a pointer `ListNode` `ptr` to accomplish our task. To check if a duplicate for `ptr.val` exists, we simply have to see if `ptr.next.val` is equal to `ptr.val`, because the array is sorted and duplicates are contiguous.

The following code is identical for both C# and Java:
```
if(head == null){return null;} //Don't forget this edge case
ListNode ptr = head; //Helps for returning at the end

while(ptr.next != null){ //Terminates if there is no next node(end of list)
	if(ptr.next.val == ptr.val){ //Check for duplicate next node
		ptr.next = ptr.next.next; //Delete next node
	}
	else{
		ptr = ptr.next; //Advance if no duplicate is found
	}
}
return head; //Return the original start of list
```

The effect of our code is as such:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/081e8010-3642-4eff-bcba-68c30d95c893_1655785996.077856.png)

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
As the values are ``sorted``, we can just compare the current value with the next value to check for ``duplicates``. Traversing through the linked list and checking for this condition in each node will solve the problem.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
- Start with assigning the current node to the head of the linked list
- Traverse through the link list and ``compare`` the ``current`` node value with the ``next`` node value. If the values are same then ``current.next`` should point to ``current.next.next``. This will skip the next node
- While traversal we should also check if  ``current.next`` exists. If not then terminate the loop
- After succesful traversal the derived link list will contain no duplicates
- Return the ``head``

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        current = head
        while current and current.next:
            if current.val == current.next.val: current.next = current.next.next
            else: current = current.next
        return head
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
Beats

# Code
```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: ListNode) -> ListNode:
        # Check if the linked list is empty
        if not head:
            return None
        
        # Initialize two pointers: current and previous
        prev = head
        current = head.next
        
        while current:
            # If the current node's value is equal to the previous node's value, delete the current node
            if current.val == prev.val:
                prev.next = current.next
                current = current.next
            # If the current node's value is different, move the pointers to the next node
            else:
                prev = current
                current = current.next
        
        return head

```

solutions.content:
Hello **Tenno Leetcoders**,

For this problem, we want to remove nodes with duplicated values and return a new sorted linked list

### Iterative Step

	1) One of the edge cases, we need to watch out for is when our `head` is `None`  then we simply return `None`

	2) Our first node will become our current head 

	3) We will only perform removal process if current.next has a node and check for the following:
	
		- if current head value equals to next node value, then remove the duplicated node by setting next node 
		to the node after the duplicated node 
		
		-  If not equal, we will check the next node 
	
	4) We will then return the de-duped linked list by returning the head

### Code
```
   def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        
        if not head: return None
        
        current = head
        print(current)
         
        while current.next:
            
            if current.val == current.next.val:
                current.next = current.next.next
            else:
                current = current.next   
                
        return head
```


#### Time Complexity: O(n)

#### Space Complexity: O(1)

        :type head: ListNode
        :rtype: ListNode
        """
        current = head
        while current and current.next: 
            if current.val == current.next.val:
                current.next = current.next.next
            else:
                current = current.next
        return head
        
```

solutions.content:
**Try to read explaination, mainly in the note, you will get very clear understanding how to do these kind of problems.**
* Since given linked list is in sorted manner, it is guaranteed that duplicates will be together.
* So, we check the current node value with the next node's value
	* if it is True:
		* we simply point current node's next with next node's next 
	* else:
		* we simply move our pointer to next node.

**NOTE** -
* we are not moving our currrent pointer to next after finding duplicate and changing current's next to next node's next. we are doing it only if we donot find any duplicates. **why**?
	* it will work for every case, but it will fail for the case if we have duplicates at the end.
	* let's take an example of [1, 1, 2, 3, 3]
	* while head.next:
		* head.val == head.next.val; simply point head.next = head.next.next 
		* and if we move head pointer to head.next, that is fine currpointer is at 2. head.val != head.next.val, move head pointer to next
		* head.val == head.next.val, simply point head.next = head.next.next. and if we move head pointer to head.next, now current head is at None and our LL is 1->2->3. and when we are checking while loop we get an error that None doesn't have next.
		* so if we donot move our pointer to next if we find the duplicate then we will be able to cover all the cases.
* Now, you can get doubt what if we have while condition as while head:
	* that's completely normal, here we are comparing current's value with it's next value. so at first we have to check whether curr.next is present or not.
* after every thing is done simply return the head that we stored in a temp, since we are moving our head pointer.
```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next

class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        if not head:
            return
        temp = head
        while head.next:
            if head.val == head.next.val:
                head.next = head.next.next
            else:
                head = head.next
        return temp
```

```
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: ListNode) -> ListNode:
        l1 = head
        values = set()
        while l1:
            values.add(l1.val)
            l1 = l1.next
            
        dummy = current = ListNode(0)
        values = sorted(values)
        for i in values:
            current.next = ListNode(val=int(i))
            current = current.next
                  
        current.next = None
        return dummy.next

```
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: ListNode) -> ListNode:
        if not head: return
		# We'll track the prev and current nodes.
        prev = head
        cur = head.next
		# Set the prev.next to None (we update this when we find the next != node)
        prev.next = None
        while cur:
		    # If the vals of the two nodes are the same advance cur.
            if cur.val == prev.val:
                cur = cur.next
			# Otherwise we know they are different vals.
            else:
			    # We set our prevs next to the current node.
                prev.next = cur
				# We advance cur.
                cur = cur.next
				# We advance prev.
                prev = prev.next
				# Then set prev.next to None until we find another node.
                prev.next = None
                
        return head
```

solutions.title: python3-beats-90-efficient-removal-of-duplicates-from-a-sorted-linked-list
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Our goal is to remove duplicate nodes while maintaining the order. Since the list is sorted, duplicate nodes will be adjacent to each other. We just need to skip them.

# Approach
1. We start with a pointer called `curr` that initially points to the `head` of the linked list.
1. We use a while loop to iterate through the linked list as long as `curr` is not None and `curr.next` is not None. This loop will help us traverse the linked list and examine each pair of adjacent nodes.
1. Inside the loop, we compare the value of the current node `curr `with the value of the next node `curr.next`.
1. If the values are equal, it means we've found a duplicate node. In this case, we **update the next pointer of the current node** `curr` **to skip the next node and directly point to the node after the duplicate.** This effectively removes the duplicate node from the linked list.
1. If the values are not equal i.e. not duplicates, we move the `curr` **pointer** **one step forward** to examine the next pair of nodes.
1. The loop continues until we reach the end of the linked list or until we've checked all pairs of adjacent nodes.
1. Finally, we return the head of the modified linked list.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The algorithm iterates through the entire linked list once. Thus, the time complexity is $$O(n)$$, where n is the number of nodes in the linked list.

- Space complexity:
We are using only a constant amount of extra space to store the curr pointer. No additional data structures are used, so the space complexity is $$O(1)$$.

# Code
```

class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        curr = head

        while curr and curr.next:
            if curr.val == curr.next.val:
                curr.next = curr.next.next
            else:
                curr = curr.next
        
        return head
```

solutions.content:
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The list is already sorted so we only need to check the consecutive ListNode values.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

    1. Check the base condition.
    2. Traverse the list to access the element.
    3. Compare the consecutive node values. 
    4. Remove the duplicate elements.
    5. Finally, return the head node.
Follow the code below to understand the solution.

              **If this solution helped you, give it an up-vote to help others** 

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * public class ListNode {
 *     int val;
 *     ListNode next;
 *     ListNode() {}
 *     ListNode(int val) { this.val = val; }
 *     ListNode(int val, ListNode next) { this.val = val; this.next = next; }
 * }
 */
class Solution {
    public ListNode deleteDuplicates(ListNode head) {

        //Step: 1
        //if the list is empty, return null.
        if(head == null) return head;
        
        //initialize preNode from head.
        ListNode preNode = head;

        //initialize curNode from head.next.
        ListNode preNode = head.next;


        //Step: 2
        //Traverse till the last node.
        while(curNode != null)
        {
            //Step: 3
            //if the consecutive nodes have duplicate value.
            if(preNode.val==curNode.val)
            {
                //Step: 4
                //change the pointers to delete curNode.
                preNode.next=curNode.next;
            }
            //if the values are not duplicate.
            else
            {
                //Simply, update the preNode to curNode.
                preNode=curNode;
            }
            //curNode reference will get updated in both cases.
            //So, write it out of if-else block.
            curNode=curNode.next;
        }

        //Step: 5
        //Finally, return the head node.
        return head;
        
    }
}
```

Hi Leets! I have solved it using a simple and efficient way. The algorithm I thought is that we will traverse through the linked list and if our current node is equal to the next node then we will just skip the next node and go to the next node of next. Through this we will be skipping the same nodes.
```

class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        if head is None:
            return head
        current = head
        nxt = head.next
        while nxt is not None:
            if current.val == nxt.val:
                current.next = nxt.next
                nxt = current  # If there are more than two same elements we will check them again
            current = nxt
            nxt = nxt.next
        return head
```

solutions.content:
# Explaination:
This problem is asking us to delete all duplicate nodes, so after we visit a node, if there are any other nodes with the same value, delete them and only keep the first instance of that node.
**Example:** 1->1->2->3
As you can see `1` appears twice, we want to remove the duplicate, that would be the second `1`. 
After removing it the result should look like: 1->2->3

**Solution Breakdown:**
1. We create a variable `current` and initialize it to be the `head` of our linked list input
2. We setup our `while` loop to keep iterating while `current` and `current.next` are **NOT** `None`. The reason we do this is because we want to check the `current` node and one node after the `current` node and we want to compare their values to see if they are the same.
3. If the `current` node value is the same as the `current.next` value, we found a duplicate, so we change the pointer to skip the `.next` node and point to the node AFTER `current.next`. The reason why we do this is because we want to get rid of duplicates. So 1->1->2->3, the first `1` in that list will now skip the second `1` and point to the `2` like 1->2->3.
4. Notice how we don't update `current`, we only update `current.next`, this is because there can be more duplicates. Imagine our input was 1->1->1->2->3. After updating `current.next` it would become 1->1->2->3, we deleted the second `1` in the list and pointed the first `1` to the third `1`. But if we update our current to be `current.next.next` we will end up not deleting the third `1` which is also a duplicate. `current` would point to that `1` and the next node after would be `2`, then our `if` statement would not catch the duplicate. Since we didn't update the `current` we are still at the first `1` so `current.val` will be `1` and `current.next.val` will be `1` now we can delete that last one to make the list 1->2->3.
5. If `current` and `current.next` do not have the same values, we just update `current` like normal and set it to `current.next`
6. We return `head` after we finish.

**Time O(N) | Space O(1):**
Time is O(N) because at most we are just going through the entire linked list once
Space is O(1) because we don't have anything saved in memory which is scaling with our input. We only have a variable which we use to update pointers.

```
class Solution:
    def deleteDuplicates(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        current = head
        
        while current and current.next:
            if current.val == current.next.val:
                current.next = current.next.next
            else:
                current = current.next
        return head
```

```elixir
defmodule Solution do
  @spec delete_duplicates(head :: ListNode.t | nil) :: ListNode.t | nil
  def delete_duplicates(nil), do: nil
  def delete_duplicates(%ListNode{val: _, next: nil} = current_node), do: current_node
                               
  def delete_duplicates(%ListNode{val: val, next: %ListNode{val: val, next: _} = next_node} = _current_node) do 
    delete_duplicates(next_node)                      
  end
      
  def delete_duplicates(%ListNode{val: _, next: next_node} = current_node) do
    %ListNode{current_node | next: delete_duplicates(next_node)}
  end
end
```

![0_1472570012478_upload-707c3bc5-254d-4e5b-960f-7e3589b92fed](/uploads/files/1472570018113-upload-707c3bc5-254d-4e5b-960f-7e3589b92fed.png) \nI bet most C/C++ coders didn't free memory of deleted nodes in their accepted solutions. But Java is still faster than C/C++...

For C/C++ solutions, there is not enough information in the problem description to assume that the memory for those nodes was dynamically allocated, so trying to free the memory is not necessarily the correct approach. That said, ignoring memory allocation is not a habit which new C/C++ programmers should form.
Does the question guarantee that there will be only 2 similar adjacent elements ??\n\nBeacause ,if there might be case like  [1->2->2->2->3] we need to use 2 loops.

You would still only need one loop if you are using a while and comparing the current and next value of the linked list. 
Explanation: [1->2->2->2->3] as my linked list
current = head; -> val 1
Pass 1: Is 1 == 2? No, so move current to current.next which is 2
Pass 2: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 3: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so again we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 4: Is 2 == 3? No, we move current to current.next
There should be no pass five because current.next will be null since we are at the end of our linked list

Simple Approach 

In this approach we will only use single pointer and iterate over the list while checking for duplicate nodes and deleting them simultanously also.

1. Initialize a pointer to head, here I used 'temp' and iterate it over the linked list.

2. In each each iteration check if data of next node of temp and data of current node of temp are equal or not , if both data are equal then we have a duplicate value , so update the next node of 'temp' to temp->next->next;

3. While we update the next value of temp if duplicate value is found we also need to delete the node where duplicate value exist, NOTE:- It will be better practice if you store the node to be deleted in another variable and then delete this variable instead of directly deleting the node to be delected bcoz it may lead to errors.

4. But if the next value of temp is not equal to temp i.e no duplicate value then move the temp to next position , repeat this process and when the loop terminates you will get your list without duplicate values.
I used two pointers and got the answer from my head, it works but i don\'t know why

While we update the next value of temp if duplicate value is found we also need to delete the node where duplicate value exist, NOTE:- It will be better practice if you store the node to be deleted in another variable and then delete this variable instead of directly deleting the node to be delected bcoz it may lead to errors.

4. But if the next value of temp is not equal to temp i.e no duplicate value then move the temp to next position , repeat this process and when the loop terminates you will get your list without duplicate values.

https://siteinvokers.com/remove-duplicates-from-sorted-list-leet-code-83/\nCheck here\n

In Python, the [Optional] type is used to represent values that can either be of some type T or None. It is often used as a function parameter or return type to indicate that the function can handle or return None values in addition to values of type T. This can be useful for representing the absence of a value, or to indicate that a function may not always return a value of type T.
It is so that head can have None value, so Optional provides an option of having its value as None other than than of the mentioned type

Pass 1: Is 1 == 2? No, so move current to current.next which is 2
Pass 2: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 3: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so again we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 4: Is 2 == 3? No, we move current to current.next
There should be no pass five because current.next will be null since we are at the end of our linked list

Simple Approach 

In this approach we will only use single pointer and iterate over the list while checking for duplicate nodes and deleting them simultanously also.

1. Initialize a pointer to head, here I used 'temp' and iterate it over the linked list.

2. In each each iteration check if data of next node of temp and data of current node of temp are equal or not , if both data are equal then we have a duplicate value , so update the next node of 'temp' to temp->next->next;

3. While we update the next value of temp if duplicate value is found we also need to delete the node where duplicate value exist, NOTE:- It will be better practice if you store the node to be deleted in another variable and then delete this variable instead of directly deleting the node to be delected bcoz it may lead to errors.

4. But if the next value of temp is not equal to temp i.e no duplicate value then move the temp to next position , repeat this process and when the loop terminates you will get your list without duplicate values.
I used two pointers and got the answer from my head, it works but i don\'t know why

**Here, why do we use Optional[ListNode]? How is it useful? **
https://siteinvokers.com/remove-duplicates-from-sorted-list-leet-code-83/\nCheck here\n

In Python, the [Optional] type is used to represent values that can either be of some type T or None. It is often used as a function parameter or return type to indicate that the function can handle or return None values in addition to values of type T. This can be useful for representing the absence of a value, or to indicate that a function may not always return a value of type T.
It is so that head can have None value, so Optional provides an option of having its value as None other than than of the mentioned type

You would still only need one loop if you are using a while and comparing the current and next value of the linked list. 
Explanation: [1->2->2->2->3] as my linked list
current = head; -> val 1
Pass 1: Is 1 == 2? No, so move current to current.next which is 2
Pass 2: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 3: Is 2 == 2? Yes, so again we now we need to remove this. So we move our current.next pointer to the value after that
Pass 4: Is 2 == 3? No, we move current to current.next
There should be no pass five because current.next will be null since we are at the end of our linked list

Simple Approach 

In this approach we will only use single pointer and iterate over the list while checking for duplicate nodes and deleting them simultanously also.

1. Initialize a pointer to head, here I used 'temp' and iterate it over the linked list.

2. In each each iteration check if data of next node of temp and data of current node of temp are equal or not , if both data are equal then we have a duplicate value , so update the next node of 'temp' to temp->next->next;

3. While we update the next value of temp if duplicate value is found we also need to delete the node where duplicate value exist, NOTE:- It will be better practice if you store the node to be deleted in another variable and then delete this variable instead of directly deleting the node to be delected bcoz it may lead to errors.

4. But if the next value of temp is not equal to temp i.e no duplicate value then move the temp to next position , repeat this process and when the loop terminates you will get your list without duplicate values.

**Here, why do we use Optional[ListNode]? How is it useful? **
https://siteinvokers.com/remove-duplicates-from-sorted-list-leet-code-83/\nCheck here\n

In Python, the [Optional] type is used to represent values that can either be of some type T or None. It is often used as a function parameter or return type to indicate that the function can handle or return None values in addition to values of type T. This can be useful for representing the absence of a value, or to indicate that a function may not always return a value of type T.
It is so that head can have None value, so Optional provides an option of having its value as None other than than of the mentioned type

title: Customers Who Never Order
question_content:
Table: Customers

+-------------+---------+
| Column Name | Type    |
+-------------+---------+
| id          | int     |
| name        | varchar |
+-------------+---------+
id is the primary key (column with unique values) for this table.
Each row of this table indicates the ID and name of a customer.

 

Table: Orders

+-------------+------+
| Column Name | Type |
+-------------+------+
| id          | int  |
| customerId  | int  |
+-------------+------+
id is the primary key (column with unique values) for this table.
customerId is a foreign key (reference columns) of the ID from the Customers table.
Each row of this table indicates the ID of an order and the ID of the customer who ordered it.

 

Write a solution to find all customers who never order anything.

Return the result table in any order.

The result format is in the following example.

 

Example 1:

Input: 
Customers table:
+----+-------+
| id | name  |
+----+-------+
| 1  | Joe   |
| 2  | Henry |
| 3  | Sam   |
| 4  | Max   |
+----+-------+
Orders table:
+----+------------+
| id | customerId |
+----+------------+
| 1  | 3          |
| 2  | 1          |
+----+------------+
Output: 
+-----------+
| Customers |
+-----------+
| Henry     |
| Max       |
+-----------+

solutions.title: easy-solution
easy-pandas-2-methods-with-detailed-explanation
solutions.content:
# Code -1
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    # Select the customers whose 'id' is not present in the orders DataFrame's 'customerId' column.
    df = customers[~customers['id'].isin(orders['customerId'])]

    # Build a DataFrame that only contains the 'name' column and rename it as 'Customers'.
    df = df[['name']].rename(columns={'name': 'Customers'})

    return df

```
# Explanation
- df = customers[\~customers['id'].isin(orders['customerId'])]: In this line, we use boolean indexing to filter the rows from the 'customers' DataFrame. The condition \~customers['id'].isin(orders['customerId']) checks if the 'id' column in the 'customers' DataFrame is not present in the 'customerId' column of the 'orders' DataFrame. The tilde (~) operator negates the result, so we select only the rows where the 'id' is not found in the 'customerId' column of the 'orders' DataFrame.

- df = df[['name']].rename(columns={'name': 'Customers'}): After filtering, we create a new DataFrame df containing only the 'name' column. The [['name']] part is used to select only the 'name' column and keep it as a DataFrame. Then, we rename this column from 'name' to 'Customers' using the rename function. The resulting DataFrame df contains the names of customers who never placed any orders, and the column is labeled as 'Customers'.


In summary, the find_customers function takes two DataFrames, 'customers' and 'orders', and filters the 'customers' DataFrame to find customers whose 'id' is not present in the 'orders' DataFrame's 'customerId' column. It then returns a new DataFrame with the names of these customers, labeled as 'Customers'. This function effectively finds customers who never placed any orders.

# Code -2
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    # Merge the customers DataFrame with the orders DataFrame using a left join on 'id' and 'customerId'
    merged_df = customers.merge(orders, how='left', left_on='id', right_on='customerId')
    
    # Use the 'customerId' column to create a boolean mask for customers who never placed any orders
    mask = merged_df['customerId'].isna()
    
    # Filter the rows using the boolean mask
    result_df = merged_df[mask]
    
    # Select only the 'name' column from the result DataFrame and rename it as 'Customers'
    result_df = result_df[['name']].rename(columns={'name': 'Customers'})
    
    return result_df
```
# Approach
- We first merge the 'customers' DataFrame with the 'orders' DataFrame using a left join. This allows us to have a DataFrame where each row represents a customer and includes any orders they may have placed.

- We create a boolean mask named mask by checking if the 'customerId' column in the merged DataFrame is null. This mask will be True for customers who never placed any orders and False for customers who placed orders.

- We use the boolean mask mask to filter the rows from the 'customers' DataFrame, selecting only those customers who never placed any orders.

- We select only the 'name' column from the filtered DataFrame and rename it as 'Customers'.

- Finally, we return the resulting DataFrame containing the names of customers who never placed any orders, labeled as 'Customers'.

This approach achieves the same goal of finding customers who never placed any orders but uses a different technique involving a left join and boolean masking.

```MySQL []
SELECT name AS Customers FROM Customers A WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM Orders B WHERE A.id = B.customerId);
```

2. Using nested Query

```MySQL []
SELECT name as customers FROM Customers WHERE id not in (SELECT customerId FROM Orders);
```

`Another Note:`

solutions.title: 183-solution-with-step-by-step-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
To find the customers who never ordered anything, we can use a LEFT JOIN between the Customers table and the Orders table. This will give us all customers with NULL orders. Here is the SQL query for this problem:

```
SELECT c.name AS Customers
FROM Customers c
LEFT JOIN Orders o ON c.id = o.customerId
WHERE o.id IS NULL;

```
This query selects the name column from the Customers table and left joins it with the Orders table on the customer ID. Then, it uses a WHERE clause to filter out the customers who have placed an order by checking for NULL values in the Orders table. Finally, the result is sorted by the customer name.

The output of the given input will be:
```
+-----------+
| Customers |
+-----------+
| Henry     |
| Max       |
+-----------+
```

solutions.title: mysql-solution-for-customers-who-never-order-problem
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The query aims to find customers who are not present in the Orders table, indicating that they have not placed any orders.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. The subquery (Select CustomerId from Orders) retrieves the customer IDs from the Orders table.
2. The main query Select Name as Customers from Customers selects the names (Name) of customers from the Customers table.
3. The where clause where Id not in (Select CustomerId from Orders) filters the customers based on their IDs, excluding those IDs that are present in the subquery result.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The time complexity of the SQL query depends on the size of the Customers and Orders tables and the efficiency of the database engine's query optimization and execution. Assuming proper indexing and optimization, the time complexity can vary but is typically in the order of O(n log n) or O(n), where n is the number of rows in the Customers table.

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The space complexity of the SQL query is determined by the memory required to store the result set, which in this case is the names of customers who have not placed any orders. The space complexity is proportional to the number of rows returned by the query.

(

)

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

select name as Customers

solutions.title: several-ways-to-solve-this-type-of-questions-in-a-not-in-b
solutions.content:
Genrally this type of questions contain more than one table (sometimes one table but comparing among fields), and the goal is to find records in table A but not in table B. More complicated questions are looking for records in table A but not in table B with certian critera (e.g. range of time, overlaps, flags, distinct values).

Similar questions: 1084, 1581, 1809, 577, 1350, 1607, 607

Similar type of questions: 
https://leetcode.com/problems/customers-who-bought-products-a-and-b-but-not-c/discuss/1220534/four-solutions-for-this-type-of-questions-in-a-and-b-andnot-c

Solution 1: Use left outer join
```
SELECT customers.Name as Customers
  FROM customers
  LEFT JOIN Orders
    ON customers.id = Orders.CustomerId
 WHERE customerId IS NULL
```

Solution 2: Put records not needed in a subquery. Then select records from table A WHERE the records are NOT IN/EXIST in the records selected by the subquery. 
```
SELECT customers.Name as Customers
  FROM customers
 WHERE ID not in (SELECT CustomerId FROM Orders)
```
Solution 3: Create a flag using SUM(CASE WHEN). And select all records with the corresponding flag. 
```
SELECT Name AS Customers
  FROM(
Select Customers.id, Name, SUM(CASE WHEN Customers.id = Orders.Customerid THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS score
  FROM Customers
  LEFT JOIN Orders
    ON Customers.id = Orders.CustomerId
 GROUP BY 1,2)a
 WHERE a.score = 0
 ```

Solution 4: If there's a range or there are multiple records for one id, using GROUP BY + HAVING (criteria) to evaluate the aggregated results. This solution does not really apply to this question..
solutions.code:
```
SELECT customers.Name as Customers
  FROM customers
  LEFT JOIN Orders
    ON customers.id = Orders.CustomerId
 WHERE customerId IS NULL
```
```
SELECT customers.Name as Customers
  FROM customers
 WHERE ID not in (SELECT CustomerId FROM Orders)
```
```
SELECT Name AS Customers
  FROM(
Select Customers.id, Name, SUM(CASE WHEN Customers.id = Orders.Customerid THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS score
  FROM Customers
  LEFT JOIN Orders
    ON Customers.id = Orders.CustomerId
 GROUP BY 1,2)a
 WHERE a.score = 0
 ```

solutions.title: pandas-sql-easy-customers-who-never-order-easy-explained
solutions.content:
First Approach
[See the Accepted and Successful Submission Detail](https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/1051717047/)

```
def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    # Perform a left join between 'Customers' and 'Orders'
    merged = customers.merge(orders, left_on='id', right_on='customerId', how='left')

    # Filter rows where 'customerId' in 'Orders' is null
    null_customerID = merged[merged['customerId'].isnull()]
    
    # # We select the 'name' column and rename the column from 'name' to 'customers' within the selected DataFrame. So, the resulting DataFrame will have a 'customers' column containing the data from the original 'name' column, but it does not change the original DataFrame. 
    renamed_column = null_customerID[['name']].rename(columns={'name': 'customers'})

    return renamed_column
```

Second Approach
[See the Accepted and Successful Submission Detail](https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/1051717306/)

```
def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    # First, extract customer id
        customer_id = customers['id']
    # Then, extract the column named 'customerId' from the orders DataFrame.
        orders_made_by_customer = orders['customerId']

    # Extract names of customers whose IDs are not in the 'customerId' column of 'Orders'
        customer_notIn_orderList = customers[~customer_id.isin(orders_made_by_customer)]

    # We select the 'name' column and rename the column from 'name' to 'customers' within the selected DataFrame. So, the resulting DataFrame will have a 'customers' column containing the data from the original 'name' column, but it does not change the original DataFrame. 
        renamed_column = customer_notIn_orderList[['name']].rename(columns={'name': 'customers'})

        return renamed_column

```

**SQL**
[See the Accepted and Successful Submission Detail](https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/1061394161/)

```
SELECT name AS Customers
FROM Customers 
WHERE Customers.id not in (
    SELECT customerId 
    FROM Orders
);
```

```
-- Select the "name" column from the "Customers" table and rename it as "Customers"
SELECT name AS Customers

-- Specify the source table as "Customers" from which data will be retrieved
FROM Customers 

-- Begin a conditional clause to filter rows
WHERE Customers.id not in (
    -- Subquery: Select the "customerId" column from the "Orders" table
    SELECT customerId 
    FROM Orders
);
-- Close the conditional clause
```

solutions.title: easy-solution-using-sub-query
solutions.content:
**Approach**
* Since we have the CustomerId column as a foreign key in the Orders table, we need to find all those customers whose Id is not present in CustomerId column of Orders table. 
* This in turn means that they haven't ordered anything.
* So, first we write a sub-query to find all the CustomerIds present in the orders table (Find customers who have ordered something)
* Then we filter those Ids from the Customers table which are not a part of the above list of Ids.


**QUERY**

```
select Name as Customers from Customers C where C.Id not in (select CustomerId from Orders);
```

solutions.title: using-isin-and-negating-it
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
* we just need to select the indicies which are not existing in the orders list
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
* First you have to know isin() function:
    * it takes a list as input, and loop over the calling object, and for each element, it check if this element exist in the provided list or not. 
    * if it exist, it set its index to True, else it set it as False.
    * Then it return list of binary (or bool True, False or 1,0)
* Then you have to know that we do not have isnotin() but to apply its logic, we use isin() then prefix it with **~** telda symbol. 
* Then you have to know rename() method, which we use it to change the name of the pd.Series column name.
* Last function to know is .loc[firstParam, secondParam], it takes two parameters
    * firstParam: it should be a list of indicies, where you want to select.
    * secondParam: it should be a list of columns, that you want to select from.  
* Then now you are ready to solve the problem easily, by just 
    1. get the customers Id column.
    2. then apply on it isin() 
    3. pass to isin(orders.customerId) to search for all the customers who did an order.
    4. then use telda **~** to get the customers who did not order.
    5. then pass this list to the first parameter of loc method.
    6. then the second parameter should be the **name** column, to retrieve the name of the customers who did not order any thing.
    7. then you have to use the rename method to change the column name from name to **Customers**.
    8. Then just create a dataframe object, and put inside it this coulmn to match the return type of the functio
    9. Then return that dataframe.
# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    

    return pd.DataFrame(customers.loc[~customers.id.isin(orders.customerId), 'name'].rename('Customers'))
```

solutions.title: pandas-left-anti-join
solutions.content:
Left anti join selects only the rows that are present in left dataFrame as per the join-condition.

In other words, 
`left-anti-join  == (left-join AND  .isna())`

Here we are using  the pandas' inbuilt `_merge` indicator
# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:

    joined_df = pd.merge(customers, orders, left_on="id", right_on="customerId", how="outer", indicator=True)
    
    return joined_df[joined_df["_merge"] == "left_only"][["name"]].rename(columns={"name": "Customers"})

```

```
# Write your MySQL query statement below

HERE Two Tables Customers/ Orders
id is the primary key of both tables. So JOIN key is Customers.id = Orders.customerId

PROBLEM:  report all customers who never order anything

STEPS: 
LEFT JOIN the Customers table with Orders table
and filter the customerId of Orders table is NULL
*/

    name AS Customers
    
FROM Customers c
LEFT JOIN Orders o
ON c.id = o.customerId 
where o.customerId is null

solutions.title: join-notes
solutions.content:
Add of two tables
1. union (combine two tables by rows and only save repeated rows once) 

```
select id, col from table 1
union
select id, col from table 2;
```

2. union all (combine two tables by rows and save repeated rows ) 
```

select id, col from table 1
union all
select id, col from table 2;
```

3. inner join
Join is like a cross-product of rows of tables and inner join is selcting the same id

```
select a.col1, a.col2, b.col2
from table1 as a **inner join** table2 as b
on a.col1 = b.col1
```

4. left join 

A \ B with the intersection of A and B
```
select a.col1, a.col2, b.col2
from table1 as a left join table2 as b
on a.col1 = b.col1
```

(if the value in a.col1 is not in b.col, assume it exists and the value is null in table 2)

only A \ B 
```
select a.col1, a.col2, b.col2
from table1 as a left join table2 as b
on b.col1 is null; 
```

only select the value in a.col1 and not in b.col

5. right join 

```
select a.col1, a.col2, b.col2
from table1 as a right join table2 as b
on a.col1 = b.col1
```

(if the value in b.col1 is not in a.col, assume it exists and the value is Null in table1)

```
select a.col1, a.col2, b.col2
from table1 as a right join table2 as b
on a.col1 is null; 
```

6. outer join 

```
 SELECT * 
    -> FROM Table_A
    -> LEFT JOIN Table_B 
    -> ON Table_A.PK = Table_B.PK
    -> UNION ALL
    -> SELECT *
    -> FROM Table_A
    -> RIGHT JOIN Table_B 
    -> ON Table_A.PK = Table_B.PK
    -> WHERE Table_A.PK IS NULL;
```

7. outer join exclude inner join

	QUESTION 1965
```
 SELECT * 
    -> FROM Table_A
    -> LEFT JOIN Table_B
    -> ON Table_A.PK = Table_B.PK
    -> WHERE Table_B.PK IS NULL
    -> UNION ALL
    -> SELECT *
    -> FROM Table_A
    -> RIGHT JOIN Table_B
    -> ON Table_A.PK = Table_B.PK
    -> WHERE Table_A.PK IS NULL;
```

ref 

https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/108582096 
https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/29234064

solutions.title: easy-merge-solution-with-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Here we need to find the cutomers who never ordered anything this can be found by merging both the table using outer join on 'customerId'.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We need to rename the id column from the customer table column as 'customerId' inorder to match with the column names on both tables. It is also required as per the output that we need to rename the name of the 'names' column as 'Customers'.

After joining both the tables we can check for the Customers with null values in the order id column.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    nOrd = pd.merge(customers.rename(columns = {'id': 'customerId', 'name': 'Customers'}), orders, on = 'customerId', how = 'outer')
    filDf = nOrd[nOrd['id'].isnull()]
    return filDf[['Customers']]
    
```

solutions.title: easy-to-understand-solution-for-beginners-using-pandas
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
changed name of id and name column to customerId and Customers to merge the table order to customers on column customerId merge is same as merge in mysql you have to define the merge type whether outer inner left right etc. then filtered replaced null values with 0 to represent that customer have 0 orders using fillna() which is used to fill in your data inplace of null. after that we save our filtered out data in a new dataframe and return customers column from it

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    customers.rename(columns={"id":"customerId","name":"Customers"}, inplace=True)
    new_df = pd.merge(customers,orders,how="left", on="customerId")
    new_df["id"].fillna(0, inplace=True)
    df = new_df[(new_df["id"]==0)]
    return df[["Customers"]]
```

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def customers_who_never_order(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df=pd.DataFrame()
    x=orders['customerId'].unique()
    df['Customers']=customers[~customers['id'].isin(x)][['name']]
    return df

solutions.title: fastest-solution-with-two-liner-code
solutions.content:
## ***Please Upvote my solution, if you find it helpful ;)***

# Intuition
The goal is to find the customers who never placed an order. To achieve this, we can utilize a LEFT JOIN operation to match customers with orders. If a customer doesn't have a corresponding order (i.e., the customerId is NULL), it means they never placed an order.

# Approach
1. Select the name column from the Customers table as Customers.
1. Perform a LEFT JOIN operation between the Customers and Orders tables using the customerId as the join condition.
1. Filter out the rows where the customerId in the Orders table is NULL. These are the customers who never placed an order.
1. Return the result, which will be the list of customer names (Customers) who never placed an order.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The time complexity of this solution depends on the size of the Customers and Orders tables. In the worst case, we may need to compare every customer with every order, resulting in a time complexity of $$O(n*m)$$, where n is the number of customers and m is the number of orders.
- Space complexity:
The space complexity of this solution depends on the size of the result set, which is the list of customers who never placed an order. In the worst case, if no customer placed an order, the result set will contain all customers, resulting in a space complexity of $$O(n)$$, where n is the number of customers.
# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
select c.name as Customers from Customers c
left join Orders o on o.customerId=c.id where o.customerId is null
```

solutions.title: mysql-query-easy-and-complete-explanation
solutions.content:
This is an example of Nested Query

In SQL SELECT we first need to give the names of COLUMN which we need in output and use "as" to change it's output name to "Customers" 
And then FROM -- To indicate the table name, from where we are taking data
Finally WHERE -- To specify the condition over row values of mentioned columns
					
Inside this WHERE we are checking the nested condition:
1. SELECT the customerId column from Orders table this will give rows of all the customers who orders
2. Now we need to take negative of above output -- "NOT IN" the rows we got from inner query to get customers who don't order


		SELECT Customers.name as Customers
		FROM Customers
		WHERE Customers.id NOT IN (
			SELECT Orders.customerId
			FROM Orders
		);

By following these steps, you can efficiently filter and extract the desired information to identify customers without any orders.

import pandas as pd

def find_customers(customers: pd.DataFrame, orders: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df = pd.merge(customers, orders, how='outer', left_on='id', right_on='customerId')
    df = df[df['customerId'] != df['customerId']]
    df.rename(columns={'name':'Customers'}, inplace=True)

    return df['Customers'].to_frame()

title: Move Zeroes
question_content:
Given an integer array nums, move all 0's to the end of it while maintaining the relative order of the non-zero elements.

Note that you must do this in-place without making a copy of the array.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [0,1,0,3,12]
Output: [1,3,12,0,0]

Example 2:

Input: nums = [0]
Output: [0]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 104
  • -231 <= nums[i] <= 231 - 1

 

Follow up: Could you minimize the total number of operations done?

solutions.content:
Hi there! Here is my solution to this problem that uses two pointers technique.

**Code:**
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: list) -> None:
        slow = 0
        for fast in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[fast] != 0 and nums[slow] == 0:
                nums[slow], nums[fast] = nums[fast], nums[slow]

            # wait while we find a non-zero element to
            # swap with you
            if nums[slow] != 0:
                slow += 1
```

**Algorithm complexity:**
*Time complexity: O(n)*. Our fast pointer does not visit the same spot twice.
*Space complexity: O(1)*. All operations are made in-place

If you like my solution, I will really appreciate your upvoting. It will help other python-developers to find it faster. And as always, I wish you an enjoyable time on LeetCode.

**Special thanks for the next comments:**
[**stanley98745**](https://leetcode.com/problems/move-zeroes/discuss/562911/two-pointers-technique-python-on-time-o1-space/513985)

solutions.content:
# 1. Solution

```
    def moveZeroes(self, nums):
        n = len(nums)
        i = 0
        for j in range(n):
            if (nums[j] != 0):
                nums[i], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[i]
                i += 1
```


# 2. Main idea
* We use` i` to keep track of position of the first zero in the list (which changes as we go).
* We use` j `to keep track of the first non-zero value after the first zero (which is pointed by `i`).
* Each time we have` i` correctly points to a zero and `j` correctly points to the first non-zero after `i`, we swap the values that store at `i` and `j`.
* By doing this, we move zeros towards the end of the list gradually until `j` reaches the end.
* And when it does, we are done.

# 3. Remarks
* No return value needed, since we are doing in-place modification.
* We use` nums[i], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[i]` to achieve the in-place modification because Python allows you to swaps values in a list using syntax: `x, y = y, x`.

****Please upvote if you find this post useful, and welcome to any further discussion!***

solutions.content:
We initialize two pointers `i = 0`, `j = 0`. Iterate `j` over `range(len(nums))`, and if `nums[j] != 0`, we swap `nums[i]` and `nums[j]`, and increment `i` by `1`. It is easy to see the loop invariant that `nums[:i+1]` contains all nonzero elements in `nums[:j+1]` with relative order preserved. Hence when `j` reaches `len(nums)-1`, `nums[:i+1]` contains all nonzero elements in `nums` with relative order preserved.

Time complexity: `O(n)`, space complexity: `O(1)`.

```
class Solution(object):
    def moveZeroes(self, nums):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :rtype: void Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        i = 0
        for j in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[j] != 0:
                nums[i], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[i]
                i += 1
```

solutions.content:
This question definitely sits high on my hate list.

**Idea**:
Start with two pointers (```l``` and ```r```) both at index zero.
The left poiner (```l```) will look for places where we have a zero. The right pointer (```r```) will look for numbers that can substitute that zero.
After that, in the main loop, we need to consider all cases.
If we found the zero spot (```nums[l] == 0```), we make a decision:
if ```nums[r]``` is a non-zero number, we have everything for a swap. Make this swap and move both pointers forward. If ```nums[r]``` is a zero, it's not good, keep looking by moving ```r```.
 Finally we have a case when ```nums[l] != 0```. Then we need to leave this cell by moving ```l``` and move ```r``` in order to keep the process going.
 
```
def moveZeroes(nums):
    l, r = 0, 0
    while r < len(nums):
        if nums[l] == 0:
            if nums[r] != 0:
                nums[l], nums[r] = nums[r], nums[l]
                l += 1
                r += 1
            else:
                r += 1
        else:
            l += 1
            r += 1
```

solutions.content:
# Solution no. 01

---


# Intuition
When approaching this problem, the idea is to perform an in-place modification of the given list of numbers. We can achieve this by first iterating through the list and moving all non-zero elements to the beginning of the list. Once we have moved all non-zero elements, we can fill the remaining positions with zeros. This approach ensures that the original order of non-zero elements is preserved while zeros are pushed to the end of the list.

# Approach
1. Initialize a variable index to keep track of the position where the next non-zero element should be placed.
1. Iterate through each element num in the nums list.
   - If num is not equal to zero, assign num to the position index in the nums list and increment index.
1. After the iteration, all non-zero elements have been placed at the beginning of the list, and index indicates the position where the first zero should be placed.
1. Iterate from index to the end of the list, assigning zero to each position to fill the remaining positions with zeros.

By following this approach, we ensure that all non-zero elements are moved to the start of the list while maintaining their original order, and the remaining positions are filled with zeros.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
    - The first pass through the list takes O(n) time to move non-zero elements to the start of the list.
    - The second pass through the list takes O(n) time to fill the remaining positions with zeros.
    - The overall time complexity is dominated by the linear passes through the list, resulting in **O(n)** time complexity.

- Space complexity:
    - The algorithm only uses a constant amount of extra space, regardless of the input size. Hence Space complexity of this code is **O(1)**
    - It modifies the input list in-place without requiring additional data structures.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        index = 0

        # Place non-zero elements at the start of the list
        for num in nums:
            if num != 0:
                nums[index] = num
                index += 1

        # Fill the remaining positions with zeroes
        while index < len(nums):
            nums[index] = 0
            index += 1
```

---



# Solution no. 02

---

# Intuition
Instead of directly filling the positions with zero after placing non-zero elements, we can maintain a pointer to indicate the position where the next non-zero element should be placed. This way, we only perform assignments when necessary, reducing the total number of assignments.

# Approach
1. Initialize a variable index to 0, which represents the position where the next non-zero element should be placed.
1. Iterate through each element num in the nums list.
1. If num is not equal to zero, swap nums[index] and nums[i], and increment index.
1. After the iteration, all non-zero elements have been moved to their correct positions, and all positions after index are filled with zeros.
1. By swapping non-zero elements with the position index, we achieve the desired result without needing a separate loop to fill remaining positions with zeros.

Complexity
- Time complexity: 
    - **O(n)**
    - The single pass through the list takes O(n) time.
    - The number of assignments is minimized, which improves the constant factors involved in the time complexity.

- Space complexity: 
    - **O(1)**
    - The algorithm only uses a constant amount of extra space for variables.
    - It modifies the input list in-place without requiring additional data structures.
    
While this alternative approach doesn't change the big-O time and space complexities, it might result in slightly better performance due to the reduced number of assignments.

```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        index = 0  
       
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[i] != 0:
                # If the current element is non-zero, swap it with the element at index
                # This effectively moves non-zero elements to the beginning of the list
                nums[i], nums[index] = nums[index], nums[i]
                index += 1 
                
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
- We initialize a pointer i to the beginning of the array. This pointer keeps track of where the next non-zero element should be placed.
- We loop through the array using another pointer j.
- If we encounter a non-zero element, we swap it with the element at the current position of i, effectively moving the non-zero element to the left of any zeroes encountered so far.
- We then increment the i pointer to move it to the next position, ready for the next non-zero element.
- Since we are modifying the input array in-place, we do not need to return anything.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
87.10%

- Space complexity:
96.33%

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        # Initialize pointer to the beginning of the array
        i = 0
        # Loop through the array
        for j in range(len(nums)):
            # If the current element is non-zero
            if nums[j] != 0:
                # Swap it with the element at the current pointer
                nums[i], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[i]
                # Increment the pointer
                i += 1

```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Sort in python is stable, so order of equal elements will be not changed
https://wiki.python.org/moin/HowTo/Sorting#Sort_Stability_and_Complex_Sorts
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Just sort them pretending that are only 2 types of values!
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n*logn)$$
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        nums.sort(key=lambda x: x == 0)
        return nums
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        # Idea: have a slow pointer pointing at the beginning and only move with condition.
        # Condition: when iterating nums, if we encounter a nonzero, swap places with the slow and increase slow by 1.
        slow = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[i]!=0:
                nums[i], nums[slow] = nums[slow], nums[i]
                slow+=1
```

solutions.content:
Algorithm:
* keep slow pointer on 0 (zero) until fast pointer meet non-zero, i.e. fast pointer move while slow pointer remain on the same value
* swap evalues
* increment both slow and fast pointers

Illustration:

```
[0,1,0,3,12] -> [1,0,0,3,12] -> [1,0,0,3,12] -> [1, 3, 0, 0, 12] -> [1, 3, 0, 0, 12]  -> [1, 3, 12, 0, 0]
 | |               | |             |   |               |  |                |      |                 |  | 
 s f               s f             s   f               s  f                s      f                 s  f 
```
         
Code:
          
```
slow = 0
fast = 1
length = len(nums) - 1
        
while slow <= length and fast <= length:
	if nums[slow] == 0 and nums[fast] != 0:
		nums[slow] = nums[fast]
        nums[fast] = 0
            
    if nums[slow] != 0:
		slow += 1

    fast += 1
        
return nums
```

Time complexity: O(n)
Space complexity: O(1)

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Copy and move destination synchronously with source or skip zeroes.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Find the first zero-cell. It will be the start for writing.

Skip zeros or copy content and move source and destination places synchronously.

Fill with zeroes to the end.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
- Code complexity: 2 one-purpose vars, 3 cycles, 1 condition

# Code
```
class Solution {
    public void moveZeroes(int[] nums) {
        int dst = -1;
        while (++dst < nums.length && nums[dst] != 0); // Find first zero
        int src = dst;
        while (++src < nums.length)
            if (nums[src] != 0)           // Skip
                nums[dst++] = nums[src];  // or copy content
        while (dst < nums.length)
            nums[dst++] = 0;              // Fill with zeroes to the end!
    }
}
```

solutions.content:
This is my way, very pythonic, although I admit this is a little bit tricky because it use del. In the other language, there is no such method.
   ```
 def moveZeroes(self, nums):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :rtype: void Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        length = len(nums)
        i,j = 0,0
        while(i < length):
            if nums[j] == 0:
                del nums[j]
                nums.append(0)
                i += 1
                continue
            j += 1
            i += 1
```
Notice j is the real index and i is actually the number of operation time.

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We define the left pointer $l$ that points to the place we will move the next non-zero number to.

The right pointer $r$ would go through the array. Two cases here:

1. If nums[r] == 0, do nothing.
2. Otherwise, we set nums[l]=nums[r] and increment $l$ by one.

After the right pointer is done going through the array, the pointer $l$ would be **EXACTLY** at the place we setting elements to zero at. So we just simply move $l$ to the end of the array setting all elements to zero.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
func moveZeroes(nums []int)  {
    l := 0

    for r := range nums {
        if nums[r] != 0 {
            nums[l] = nums[r]
            l++
        }
    }
    for ; l < len(nums); l++ {
        nums[l] = 0
    }
    return
}
```

```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        i = 0
        j = 1
        
        while j < len(nums):
            if nums[i] == nums[j] and nums[i] == 0:
                j += 1
                continue
            
            if nums[i] == 0 and nums[j] != 0:
                # swap elements
                temp = nums[j]
                nums[j] = nums[i]
                nums[i] = temp
            
            i += 1
            j += 1
```

# Use sort to solve this problem
## Code
```python
def move_zeroes(self, nums):
    nums.sort(key=lambda n: n == 0)
```

## Explain
1. Python lists have a built-in `list.sort()` method that modifies the list in-place.
2. The key parameter to specify  `lambda n: n == 0` called on each num in nums prior to making comparisons
3. So all zero will be sort to the right, none zero will keep in origin order

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We need to use pointers to move our zeros to the very end somehow by using the same datastructure and minimize the steps and time complexity of the algorithm. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We can utilize a two-pointer approach to solve this problem. The first pointer tracks the position of the last encountered non-zero element (initialized to zero), while the second pointer traverses the list. When we come across a non-zero element, we swap it with the element at the position indicated by the first pointer, and then increment the first pointer. This process ensures that all non-zero elements are shifted to the front of the array, while preserving their relative order. Finally, we fill the remaining elements with zeros.

If you find this helpful, please consider liking this post. I'll continue to share more solutions like this. Should you have any questions, feel free to comment below, and I'll respond as promptly as possible.


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(n)
We are traversing the entire list at worst case, so this is why our time is big o of n. n being the numbers of elements in our list. 
- Space complexity:
O(1)
since we are updating the same list we are not using any extra space. 

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def moveZeroes(self, nums: List[int]) -> None:
        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """
        zero_pos = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[i] != 0:
                nums[i], nums[zero_pos] = nums[zero_pos], nums[i]
                zero_pos += 1   



            

    
                


```

class Solution:

        """
        Do not return anything, modify nums in-place instead.
        """

Anyone please tell -------------------------------
[@nikhila01](/nikhila01)  Thanks bro now I understand

When you do `nums = nums + zero` you're not changing `nums` in place. You're creating a new list and assigning it to the local variable called `nums`. Once the function exits that change isn't visible.

First, don't use the name `nums` when you're creating `[x for x in nums if x!=0]`. Give it another name like `nonzero`, otherwise you lose access to the original input list.

Then try doing `nums[:] = nonzero + zero` which will actually copy the elements into `nums`.
Easy solution check if number is not equal to 0 then swap with next number.\nhttps://leetcode.com/problems/move-zeroes/solutions/3100334/easy-java-solution/

I tired using pop by index to remove zeroos and append 0 at last each time on popping.
But my solution failed for,
nums = [0,1,0]
Not able to figure out why?
Please let me know.

 `        # can i pop element based on index.

        for i in range(len(nums)):
            # print('ele', nums[i])
            if nums[i] == 0:
                del nums[i]
                # print('pop', nums.pop(i))
                # print('num', nums)
                nums.append(0).`

TLDR:
a forward for-loop requires your i to increase by 1
but popping from the front affects the index of your elements



when you pop the list from the beginning , it's length changes by -1, thereby changing the index of its elements 
(i.e. some element's index would decreases by 1 if an element preceding it was popped)

but at the same time you are running a for-loop where the loop's iteration index i is assumed to steadily increase by 1 per loop

e.g.
let's assume I want to pop the i-th element in the following list, per each for-loop cycle:
~~~

list = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
(0 is at index 0;
 1 is at index 1;
 2 is at index 2... etc.)

run a for-loop for i = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
for i in range(0,5):

first loop; i = 0:
list.pop(i)
(0 is popped)
list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
(note that 1 is now at index 0, when it was at index 1 previously; 
same for all other numbers in the list; their index has shifted by -1)

second loop; i = 1:
list.pop(i)
(2 is popped)
list = [1, 3, 4, 5]
(popping the 1-th element shifts the index of everything after it by -1)

third loop; i = 2:
list.pop(i)
(4 is popped)
list = [1, 3, 5]

fourth loop: i = 3:
list.pop(i)

>> Error: index out of range
(we can't pop an element in index 3
when the list = [1, 3, 5] only has elements in index 0,1,2!)

~~~~
your standard (forward) for-loop increases the i-index by 1 every cycle
but popping 'moves' your index back by 1 every cycle,

so you are decreasing your index as i increases in each iteration of the for-loop, 
causing them to go out-of-sync (and throw an index-out-of-range error, eventually)

meanwhile, you'll also be popping the elements at the wrong indexes!
(in the example above, the originally intention was to pop every element, but I ended up popping every second element instead)


solution: 
try using a for-loop that goes backward, starting from n-1 and ends at -1

alternatively, you can implement a counter-variable that can be subtracted from your i to give you a 'true' index
https://youtu.be/-Qpk2XJ5XJQ
